Bidens 80% electricity from clean energy by 2030 is BS.  So says the following year 2020 figures from the Energy Information Administration.

There won't be any increase in nuclear power for plants have been generating in excess of capacity since 1990.  Hydroelectric - no change.  BioMass - is 1.4% but it is not clean for wood is burned to make electricity, releasing co2..  

This leaves Wind (338billion) and solar 91 billion.  In 2020 this was about 10.6% of electricity generated yet the capacity is 23%.  Wind and solar produce at less then 50% capacity, the most inefficient of the present sources of generation.

W&S Constructed capacity would have to increase 8 fold (to 3.2TKW)  in 9 years to reach 1.6Tkw of generated electricity too offset the fossil fuel reduction.

text:
DIVORCE AGREEMENT 
Between Republicans & Democrats
             WRITTEN BY A YOUNG COLLEGE STUDENT
                 The person who wrote this is a college (law) student.
THIS IS SO INCREDIBLY WELL PUT AND I CAN HARDLY BELIEVE IT'S BY                                 A YOUNG PERSON, A STUDENT! 
 
Dear American liberals, leftists, social progressives, socialists, Marxists,  Obama and Biden supporters, et al:
 
We have stuck together  since the late 1950's for the sake of the kids, but the whole of this latest election process has made me realize that I want a divorce. I know we tolerated each other for many years for the sake of future generations, but sadly, this relationship has clearly run its course. Our two ideological sides of America cannot and will not ever agree on what is right for us all, so let's just end it on friendly terms. We can smile and chalk it up to irreconcilable differences and go our own way.
 
Here is our separation agreement: 

--Our two groups can equitably divide up the country by landmass each taking a similar portion. That will be the difficult part, but I am sure our two sides can come to a friendly agreement. After that, it should be relatively easy! Our respective representatives can effortlessly divide other assets since both sides have such distinct and disparate tastes.
 
--We don't like re-distributive taxes so you can keep them.
 
--You are welcome to the liberal judges and the ACLU
 
--Since you hate guns and war, we'll take our firearms, the cops, the NRA, and the military.
 
--We'll take the nasty, smelly oil industry and the coal mines, and you can go with wind, solar and bio-diesel
 
--You can keep Oprah, Michael Moore, and Rosie O'Donnell. You are, however, responsible for finding a bio-diesel vehicle big enough to move all three of them.
 
--We'll keep capitalism, greedy corporations, pharmaceutical companies, Wal-Mart, and Wall Street.
 
--You can have your beloved lifelong welfare dwellers, food stamps, hippies, druggies, and illegal aliens.

--You can keep Goggle, Twitter and Facebook.  We can straighten out Amazon.
 
--We'll keep the hot Alaskan hockey moms, greedy CEOs, and rednecks
 
--We‚Äôll keep Hannity, Carlson, and Bibles, and give you NBC, CNN, ABC, CBS, and Hollywood
 
--You can make nice with Iran and Palestine and we'll retain the right to invade and hammer places that threaten us.
 
--You can have the peaceniks and war protesters.
 
--When our allies or our way of life are under assault, we'll help provide them security.
 
--We'll keep our Judeo-Christian values.
 
--You are welcome to Islam, Scientology, Humanism, and political correctness. You can also have the UN, but we will no longer pay the bill.
 
--We'll keep the SUV's, pickup trucks, and oversized luxury cars. You can take every Volt, Prius, and Leaf you can find.
 
--You can give everyone healthcare if you can find any practicing doctors.
 
--We'll keep "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" and 
"The National Anthem."
 
--I'm sure you'll be happy to substitute "Imagine," "I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing," "Kumbaya ‚Äúor‚Äù We Are the World."
 
--We'll practice trickle-down economics and you can continue to give trickle up poverty your best shot.
 
--Since it often so offends you, we'll keep our history, our name and our flag.
 
Would you agree to this?   If so, please pass it along to other like-minded liberal and conservative patriots and if you do not agree, just hit delete.   In the spirit of friendly parting, I'll bet you might think about which one of us will need whose help in 15 years.
 
Sincerely,
 
John J Wall
 
Law Student and American!
 
P. S.  Also, please take Ted Turner, Sean Penn, Martin & Charlie Sheen, George Clooney, Barbara Streisand, and (Hanoi) Jane Fonda with you.
 
P.S.S. And you won't have to press 1 for English when you call our country.
 
Forward This Every Time You Get It!   

            Let's Keep This Going,
Maybe Some of It Will Start Sinking In!

 
--

text:
Carbon taxes are folly. Deforestation is the problem. Reforestation or land set aside the solution. I‚Äôve witnessed it with my own eyes. 

Born and bred in Africa I witnessed much of the climate change in Zimbabwe as forests were cut down for grain and tobacco cultivation and 80% of the land changed to grassland and semi-desert. The EU land set aside restores nature‚Äôs powers over the climate, fixing carbon dioxide and stabilising temperatures and rainfall.  Why else is earth‚Äôs atmospheric carbon dioxide just 0.04% when it straddles between Venus and Mars orbits each planet with atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations in excess of 90%? Carbon dioxide is not the demon, it is plant food and plants work for us providing us with food and controlling our climate to be most favourable for life. Carbon dioxide and fossil fuels are just side actors, just like police cars and ambulances are to accident scenes. Just because police cars and ambulances are present at every accident scene does not mean that they caused them. The same with carbon dioxide and fossil fuels, they were mere agents of deforestation but deforestation was the cause of environmental changes. 

So the solution to gaining control over our environment is strengthening nature. 

The first method can be used by you personally to indirectly alter the climate for the better. Change to a keto or paleo diet and minimise your carbohydrate intake. This will not only improve your health and eliminate T2D, but more importantly it will incentivise farmers to plant trees which bind soils and provide nuts and seeds for your keto diet. If you choose a high carbohydrate diet, farmers will respond by cutting down forests to grow grain for your food. So by altering your food intake to a keto or paleo diet, you alter the food chain and thus ultimately the climate. 

See the best keto diet here https://youtu.be/gxLSxt2IKiQ

The second (macro) solution can bring about climate improvement is as follows. 

1) Build plant factories to feed 7.8 billion people and liberate land and water for forests
https://youtu.be/dnCQuwCtqJg

2) Use cattle herds to revitalise soil

3) Use goats to reduce fire dangers in forests

4) Use agrivoltaics to turn deserts into meadows with solar panels

5) Use marine cloud seeding to moisten and seed ocean air for clouds and rain
https://youtu.be/Awf1W0-UMR4

6) Use minerals to assist salmon populations 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Salmon_Restoration_Corporation

Don‚Äôt be misanthropic with the debunked carbon dioxide nonsense. Be positive. Be useful. Help flora and fauna control climate and don‚Äôt demonise plant food.

text:
Do You Understand that Democrats will Destroy America?
By Carol Greenwald
I earn my living investing other people‚Äôs money in the stock market. I am terrified contemplating how I am going to save my clients‚Äô money, as well as my own, if a Democrat is elected president. The policies that the Democrats are advocating will destroy the American economy, not just the stock market, but the whole US economy. My first instinct will be to raise cash ahead of the stock market crash, but even that is only a temporary safe harbor.
The Green New Deal, renewed regulations, Medicare for All, free college, as well as the 70-90% tax rates proposed by Democrats, will tank the stock market and US economic growth, leading to higher unemployment and reduced wage gains. All these programs require higher taxes and not just the soak the rich fantasy of the 70-90% rates. Most of the Democratic candidates have pledged to roll back the 2017 Republican tax cuts that fueled the renewal of economic growth in the US.
Open borders will flood the US with poverty stricken immigrants and their competition for jobs will depress wages. The social welfare needs of the immigrants will skyrocket government expenditures. So while taxes receipts are falling due to slower economic growth rates, expenditures will be rising, leading to increased government debt and consequently higher interest rates. If the Federal Reserve tries to keep interest rates low to prevent a deepening recession, then the increase in the money supply and the expanding deficit will eventually destroy the value of the dollar. So much for my safe harbor in cash.
Immigration: What do Open Borders Mean?
Milton Friedman pointed out over a decade ago, you cannot have open borders and a social welfare state‚Ä¶ the supply of immigrants will become infinite.
Virtually all of the Democratic candidates have advocated for opening the border to all who want to come. All the Democratic candidates on the second night of the debate supported free health benefits for illegal immigrants and several have advocated for free college for all. But even without these additional incentives, the level of living available in the US, even to the poorest Americans, far exceeds what many of the world‚Äôs peoples can hope for in their own countries. No one starves in America. Our poor have cars, large screen TVs, air conditioning, video games for their kids and eat better than the average GI in World War II.
This is an invitation to all the world‚Äôs poor to come to the US in unlimited numbers. All you need is to get to our southern border. The number of people living in poverty in Latin America in 2017 was 184 million.
But immigration will not be limited to the poverty stricken in our own hemisphere. There are 750 million people who live below the international poverty line of $1.90 a day. By that standard, those coming from Latin America are not the most desperate. People will find a way to come to the US from Africa, possibly trafficked by cartels and other criminal gangs, as are many coming from Latin America now. (Have you ever wondered how poverty stricken people manage to travel 1400 miles, often with children and obtain food and water for the trip, and then arrive at our southern border in non-ragged clothes?) Since May of this year, 1100 illegal immigrants from Africa were interdicted at the southern US border. More will be coming.
With open borders, the economy of the US will sink under the demands for social services to be provided for a population that will overwhelm citizens living here now. But those advocating open borders do not put America first. They are ‚Äúcitizens of the world‚Äù and feel it is unfair that Americans have a higher standard of living than others. They will ensure that we don‚Äôt for much longer.
Tax the Rich Delusion
The race for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination is quickly becoming a contest to determine which candidate wants to tax the rich the most. Democratic candidates have been attracted to Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez‚Äôs proposal to tax incomes over $10 million at a 70% rate. Not to be outdone, Ilhan Omar has proposed a 90% top rate.
But what are the benefits and costs of these proposals beyond the fun of calling to soak the rich? According to the Tax Foundation, a 70% tax on all income over $10 million would raise only $51.4 billion over ten years and lose revenue in the first two years of its enactment because people would forego capital gains. The federal budget is estimated to collect $3.645 trillion in taxes in fiscal 2019, so the increased tax revenue will be trivial in terms of changing the actual amount of taxes the US government will have to spend, but it will have strong disincentives on entrepreneurship. It is America‚Äôs high rate of innovation and entrepreneurship that account for American economic success and wealth.
Medicare for All
The cost of Medicare for All means that the availability of Medicare for those on it now will be sharply reduced. The current level of Medicare cannot be provided to vastly more people without bankrupting the country. But even if it could, services would have to be cut sharply because we do not have the doctors and hospital beds to service vast new numbers of eligible people. Some candidates like Bernie Sanders admit that you will not be able to keep your private health insurance even if you want to, and that your taxes will go up to pay for this new benefit; others like Joe Biden lie and say if you like your plan you can keep your plan and Sen. Kamala Harris denies that your taxes will rise. But Medicare for all will be another costly program that will increase the national debt.
The Green New Deal
To those who believe that climate change is the existential threat facing America (not Iran or China), destroying the US economy to save the planet is a fair trade. Doing away with fossil fuels now that the US has become the world‚Äôs largest provider of oil and natural gas and has become energy independent is a sure way to cripple the US economy and to hand economic might to China and Russia who will not face the same restrictions. So not only will the Green New Deal destroy the US economy, but possibly also our freedom, as we decline economically and our adversaries, China and Russia, continue growing in economic strength without these restrictions.
Trump is the only choice
Whatever you think of President Trump, you know by his record that he will put America first and that his policies have created a robust economy. Unless you want to see the US economy and your standard of life destroyed, there is no alternative to voting for President Trump.

text:
Here's a fun anecdote that shows how much they really care. It's long but true. 
My father was a race car driver in the 60s/70s. In his travels he got to know a guy named Ralph Moody who was an engine wizard that built NASCAR engines in the early Richard petty era. In the 70s there were multiple gas shortages which inspired him to build mainstreet engines focused on gas mileage. He did so. (I heard this story straight from the horse's mouth). He built a diesel car engine that got 90 miles per gallon & a standard engine that got 68 in the 1970s. During an advertisement campaign where Moody drove his "Moody Diesel" from coast to coast in 1979 when smog was 1st becoming an issue he was repeatedly pulled over by cops (almost as if they were ordered to harass him) During this process his car was repeatedly inspected with smog detectors... They couldn't register a reading because the engine burned cleaner than anything that has ever hit the road... 
Moody's engines would also come with a lifetime guarentee to never break btw. 
After going public, offers to buy his patents started rolling in, & so did threats in late night phone calls.  Eventually Moody sold his patents for 90% less than original offers because the EPA ruled his engine unfit citing "unknown long term environmental impact." In other words a clean burning engine that got 5x the MPG than average cars in the late 70s & came with a lifetime guarentee was shut down... by the "Environmental Protection Agency" LOL!!! 
Out of fear he would be killed for informing the public that engines 10x better than what we had could be available anytime Moody sold his patents & signed a non compete clause agreeing to never build anything of the kind again. That technology has sat in a vault somewhere since 1980 while the government continues to use the "climate crisis" as one of it's biggest money makers for their corporate masters.
author: Scott Broyles

text:
From the below posted Dec 10, 2020 Forbes article titled "The UN Says America Is Already Cutting So Much Carbon It Doesn't Need The Paris Climate Accord" : Yesterday, The United Nations released its¬†Emissions Gap Report 2020, an annual assessment of contributions to greenhouse gas and carbon emissions. The report has some notable information amid an array of complicated projections that may or may not come true. It claims, for instance, that ‚Äúdespite a brief dip in carbon dioxide emissions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, the world is still heading for a temperature rise.‚Äù¬†
But for the United States, the real value in this report is as an advisory that it need not join the Paris Climate Accord. This report is evidence that, instead, the U.S. should just keep doing what it is doing to cut its own emissions. The U.S. is the most successful major country at mitigating its own pollution, and the U.N. shows this.¬†

text:
¬†@Pharma Data¬† One could claim that it is ‚Äúfull of political purpose‚Äù to NOT cut fossil fuel usage as well, and/or claim that it is ‚Äúfull of political purpose‚Äù to claim that it is ‚Äúfull of political purpose‚Äù to cut fossil fuels. My point is everyone has a different opinion/strategy on how to keep people healthy, educated, and living comfortably. 

Now, when it comes to global warming, it is mostly natural (the precession of the Earth changing; water vapor being the most abundant greenhouse gas; and the Sun‚Äôs activity), but it is also found to be partly anthropogenic. Carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide trap heat and can also cause water vapor to become more concentrated in our upper atmosphere, creating more of a heating effect. 

As for nuclear power, I agree, that could help. We could add onto that more hydroelectric power dams and allow for universal net metering, to encourage more people to generate their own power (as it would cost less)‚Äîthat generation tending to be cleaner (solar panels, mini wind turbines, and geothermal power).

text:
Go ahead and try to remove the 0.000094 mole fraction increase of CO2 in the atmosphere. The amount of increase since 1960 according to NASA.  This will not make any difference.

Want to control the climate?  First, you need to find a way to regulate the nuclear fusion process in the sun.  Second, you need to keep the earth‚Äôs magnetosphere at a constant level.  Third, stop the earth from its ongoing increase in axial tilt which is causing the arctic circle to march northwards at almost 50 feet every year (remember, the earth‚Äôs oceans have 1,000,000 times more heat capacity than the atmosphere).  Do these, and then you have a shot.  Do them not, and nothing else matters.

Better to worry about NEOs, near earth objects. The next biggy will be close to earth in 2029.  NASA has changed its mind about the probability of this striking earth from likely to now unlikely but that can change. NEOs will cause an extinction level event far sooner than the climate changing significantly, which will be about 100,000 years.

author: L·éæN·é∂E ·éæP·èÜIMU–Ö

text:
¬†@L·éæN·é∂E ·éæP·èÜIMU–Ö¬† "Paris agreement even though every sane scientist on this planet recommends following it." 

Paris climate promises will reduce temperatures by just 0.05¬∞C in 2100 

A new peer-reviewed paper by Dr. Bjorn Lomborg published in the Global Policy journal measures the actual impact of all significant climate promises made ahead of the Paris climate summit.

Governments have publicly outlined their post-2020 climate commitments in the build-up to the December‚Äôs meeting. These promises are known as ‚ÄúIntended Nationally Determined Contributions‚Äù (INDCs). 

Dr. Lomborg‚Äôs research reveals:

    The climate impact of all Paris INDC promises is minuscule: if we measure the impact of every nation fulfilling every promise by 2030, the total temperature reduction will be 0.048¬∞C (0.086¬∞F) by 2100.
    Even if we assume that these promises would be extended for another 70 years, there is still little impact: if every nation fulfills every promise by 2030, and continues to fulfill these promises faithfully until the end of the century, and there is no ‚ÄòCO‚ÇÇ leakage‚Äô to non-committed nations, the entirety of the Paris promises will reduce temperature rises by just 0.17¬∞C (0.306¬∞F) by 2100. 
    US climate policies, in the most optimistic circumstances, fully achieved and adhered to throughout the century, will reduce global temperatures by 0.031¬∞C (0.057¬∞F) by 2100.
    EU climate policies, in the most optimistic circumstances, fully achieved and adhered to throughout the century, will reduce global temperatures by 0.053¬∞C (0.096¬∞F) by 2100.
    China climate policies, in the most optimistic circumstances, fully achieved and adhered to throughout the century, will reduce global temperatures by 0.048¬∞C (0.086¬∞F) by 2100.
    The rest of the world‚Äôs climate policies, in the most optimistic circumstances, fully achieved and adhered to throughout the century, will reduce global temperatures by 0.036¬∞C (0.064¬∞F) by 2100.

Overview in Celsius and Fahrenheit by the year 2100

What does this mean for the Paris Summit?

Dr. Lomborg said: ‚ÄúParis is being sold as the summit where we can help ‚Äòheal the planet‚Äô and ‚Äòsave the world‚Äô. It is no such thing. If all nations keep all their promises, temperatures will be cut by just 0.05¬∞C (0.09¬∞F). Even if every government on the planet not only keeps every Paris promise, reduces all emissions by 2030, and shifts no emissions to other countries, but also keeps these emission reductions throughout the rest of the century, temperatures will be reduced by just 0.17¬∞C (0.3¬∞F) by the year 2100. 

And let‚Äôs be clear, that is very optimistic. Consider the Kyoto Protocol, signed in 1997, never ratified by the US, and eventually abandoned by Canada and Russia and Japan. After several renegotiations, the Kyoto Protocol had been weakened to the point that the hot air left from the collapse of the Soviet Union exceeded the entire promised reductions, leaving the treaty essentially toothless. 

The only reason Kyoto goals were almost achieved was the global 2008 recession.  Moreover, emissions were shifted from one country to another. The EU, the most climate-engaged bloc, saw an increase in its emission imports from China alone equaling its entire domestic CO‚ÇÇ reductions. In total, 40% of all emissions were likely shifted away from the areas that made promises.

Negotiators in Paris are trying to tackle global warming in the same way that has failed for 30 years: by making promises that are individually expensive, will have little impact even in a hundred years and that many governments will try to shirk from. 

This didn‚Äôt work in Kyoto, it didn‚Äôt work in Copenhagen, it hasn‚Äôt worked in the 18 other climate conferences or countless more international gatherings. The suggestion that it will make a large difference in Paris is wishful thinking.‚Äù

What should countries do instead?

Dr. Lomborg said: ‚ÄúInstead of trying to make fossil fuels so expensive that no one wants them ‚Äì which will never work ‚Äì we should make green energy so cheap everybody will shift to it.

The Copenhagen Consensus on Climate project gathered 27 of the world‚Äôs top climate economists and three Nobel Laureates, who found that the smartest, long-term climate policy is to invest in green R&D, to push down the price of green energy. 

Subsidizing inefficient renewables is expensive and doesn‚Äôt work. The IEA estimates that we get 0.4% of our energy from wind and solar PV right now, and even in optimistic scenarios the fraction will only rise to 2.2% by 2040. Over the next 25 years, we‚Äôll spend about $2.5 trillion in subsidies and reduce global warming temperatures by less than 0.02¬∞C. 

Copenhagen Consensus has consistently argued for a R&D-driven approach. Fortunately, more people are recognizing that this approach is cheaper and much more likely to succeed ‚Äìincluding the Global Apollo Program which includes Sir David King, Lord Nicholas Stern, Lord Adair Turner and Lord John Browne.
You describe a 0.05¬∞C reduction, but the UN Climate Chief, Christina Figueres, said Paris could lead to a 2.7¬∞C rise instead of 4¬∞C or 5¬∞C. Why?

Christiana Figueres quote: ‚ÄúThe INDCs have the capability of limiting the forecast temperature rise to around 2.7 degrees Celsius by 2100, by no means enough but a lot lower than the estimated four, five, or more degrees of warming projected by many prior to the INDCs.‚Äù 

Dr. Lomborg said: ‚ÄúThat entirely misrepresents the world‚Äôs options. The 2.7¬∞C comes from the International Energy Agency and essentially assumes that if governments do little in Paris and then right after 2030 embark on incredibly ambitious climate reductions, we could get to 2.7¬∞C. 

That way of thinking is similar to telling the deeply indebted Greeks that just making the first repayment on their most pressing loans will put them on an easy pathway to becoming debt-free. It completely misses the point. 

Figueres‚Äô own organization estimates the Paris promises will reduce emissions by 33Gt CO‚ÇÇ in total. To limit rises to 2.7¬∞C, about 3,000Gt CO‚ÇÇ would need to be reduced ‚Äì or about 100 times more than the Paris commitments (see figure below). That is not optimism; it is wishful thinking.
http://www.lomborg.com/press-release-research-reveals-negligible-impact-of-paris-climate-promises

text:
"Great change is coming to the world, change unlike anything that humanity as a whole has ever seen before‚ÄîGreat Waves of change all converging at this time. For humanity has impacted the world in so many ways, and the results of that impact are now gathering‚Äîgathering strength, gathering force, converging at a time when humanity is largely unaware and unprepared.

These Great Waves are not one event. They are not one simple thing that happens at one time only, for humanity has set in motion forces of change now that it must contend with on an ongoing basis. For you are now living in a world of declining resources, a world whose climate has been seriously affected, a world whose ecological condition is deteriorating, a world where humanity will have to face the prospects of great shortages of food and water and the risks of disease and illness on a very large scale, even affecting the wealthy nations of the world. The balance has now been tipped and changed, and the human family as a whole must unite and gather together to deal with these great challenges." A quote from The Great Waves of Change which is newmessage org.

text: ¬†@Rob Sellers¬† The warming of the Earth is depending on Solar Flares, more Sun activity - warmer earth. Also, one big vulcanic eruption like Mount St. Helens and global temperature drops a couple of degrees. However, climate change is one thing, being carefull with resources like fossil fuels for cars or heating and all the plastics that are created a second. Make sure that the environment is protected as well. Preventing or cleaning up after chemical spills, oil spills, air pollution are things to invest in now.  Invest in infrastructure, get rid of lead water pipes that people have to drink their water from, avoid plastic in the seas, have breathable air by installing filters in factories and cars, make sure that there is enough food for everybody and grow locally so no need to transport large distances. I live in the Netherlands, we have a huge flower culture here, there is an auction house south of Amsterdam. In the past roses were grown in Africa, transported by plane to the Netherlands sold at the auction and from there flown worldwide. These movements of goods are not necessary.  I have solar panels on the roof of my house, am able to work from home now during Covid, yes I own a car and it is not electric or a hybrid (yet), but it stands idle on the driveway most of the time now.  Oh, and I am currently living 4 meters below sea level. If sea levels are going to rise, I will need an ark myself.
author: Jam Boree

text: ¬†@Rob Sellers¬† Carbon 14 dating is reliable up to 50,000 years my guy. Snow is very rare at the polls because there is very little evaporation to feed the water cycle. Ice layers are indeed annual
author: Spaceman Spiff

text: ¬†@Spaceman Spiff¬† I disagree, a lost P-38 lightning was found approximately 130‚Äô buried in sold ice in northern Greenland. It was proven that the ice layers are not an indication of years. I‚Äôve lived in the Arctic, I know this to be true. The wind blows one way all day and reverses and blows the other direction all night. The snow layers are storm events. Here‚Äôs a peculiar truth. Why are man made cubic zirconia diamonds carbon tested to be older than real diamonds? Some say it‚Äôs because the scientific community doesn‚Äôt factor a global biblical flood when performing carbon dating. That would increase pressure by the weight of water and thus changing our earth‚Äôs timeline drastically. Melt all the ice and superheat the planet and the water goes into the atmosphere. The greatest tropical paradise in the universe
author: Rob Sellers

text:
¬†@Rob Sellers¬† The Glacier Girl crashed on the south eastern coast of Greenland, a region that does get ridiculous amounts of snow because of its proximity to ‚Äúwarm‚Äù ocean currents flowing off of Europe. However, everywhere else in Greenland gets an average of 10 inches of snow per year (still more than the 4 - 8 inches that fall in the Arctic). Core sampling would be unreliable in that one specific region of Greenland, but scientists primarily operate in the northern Greenland and other cold deserts like Antarctica.

Cubic zirconia diamonds are fake diamonds: they contain zero carbon. Since carbon 14 dating measures the concentration of carbon 14 in a substance (less carbon means older), of course zirconia diamonds will be measured as extremely old. As far as I know, there is no way to properly date a fake diamond.

Remember: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence

text:
Greatest hoax in modern times. A scientifically illiterate mainstream media almost always misinterprets or abuses science due to a biased global agenda. In a survey cited by Snopes...only 1 percent of scientists trusted mainstream media to accurately report their scientific results. The general populace suffers from a form of mathematical deprivation in terms of relative proportions, as well as, an extreme dearth in updates in science that challenge the current popular consensus of the globalists. This disinformation and misinformation is, of course, assisted by the profit and agenda-driven mass media, and the unfortunate reality that this yellow journalism is actually used as a primary form of education by so many liberal thinkers. According to Quora, humans make up about one 17 trillionth of the Earth‚Äôs mass (a single flea on a solid filled basketball would have far more relative mass than all the humans on earth). If earth and people were reduced to the size of this basketball, you would not be able to see the people with the most powerful microscope...because a person would be smaller than even a subatomic particle such as a proton. With controlled media presentations...the globalists have perpetuated a big lie.

The entire population of the earth (a mere 7 billion) could all stand in Los Angeles (5 hundred square miles), far far less than a single percentage point of the earth‚Äôs surface area...which is 57,308,738 square miles (57 million). More recent studies show that volcanoes (even inactive ones), plate tectonics, and other surface phenomena, are much more vast producers of CO2 than previously thought, and that the isotopic footprint of man-made C02 production is easily confused with natural production...because they are the same. What is the real impact of humans on climate change? Essentially none. Geological, meteorological, and cosmological events, far far outweigh any human impacts. Anyone can claim this is not true...yet this is the science of the numbers and the proportions. This is not to say that our pollution doesn‚Äôt impact other humans, plants and animals in the affected polluted regions (and that‚Äôs not good)...however, this relatively miniscule source of pollution has no significant effect on climate change. Climate will change whether we like it or not.

Like the Ozone layer hoax which proved seasonal and cyclical, sensational alarmism is used to affect a global agenda and nothing more. That the coral regions of the earth‚Äôs oceans, such as the great barrier reef, are disappearing is also a myth generated by the false reporting of science (Humans have less than 1 percent impact on the natural process of coral bleaching). As well, humans use up none of the Earth‚Äôs 6 quintillion gallons of water. That is because water recycles into the earth‚Äôs enclosed ecosystems...just like CO2. Media loves to use cool science fiction art depicting all sorts of out-of-proportion disasters in the news. However, Is a nuclear blast on earth visible from the moon? No...at best you could see a very tiny reflection from its cloud dust if sun rays were to hit and a reflection were to occur. Basically a thermonuclear blast will kill living organisms in the vicinity surrounding the blast range and leave radioactivity. That‚Äôs not good for us humans...but the impact to the earth itself is again...negligible. People generally have no idea of relative proportions regarding a number of natural events. Popular science and internet media search algorithms do as little as possible to represent it clearly and accurately to the public...because they fear their agenda might be discovered for its real motive and then ignored. 

So...why is this abuse of science done? In the words of H. L. Mencken‚Ä¶‚ÄùThe urge to save humanity is almost always a false front for the urge to rule.‚Äù Yet the poison pill of socialism is of far far greater concern to human life then global warming will ever be. When a very direct and precise question is entered in current Big Tech controlled search engines, rather than getting a direct response they figure might lead to further ‚Äúdistracting‚Äù questions...detracting from their global agenda...they instead give only the answers to the questions they want you to ask. Try it...it happens all the time...especially with ‚Äúhot button‚Äù topics. The impacts of oil spills, while impacting surrounding marine life (and no one is saying its not important and a terrible thing) has nil effect on the earth itself. All of fracking is less than a single pin prick on that basketball sized globe. The likelihood it would trigger anything different from the usual course of plate tectonics is so tiny as to be zero. That people impact the earth much at all, is a logical and basic numerical fallacy. The earth was created for our use, its resources are endless in practical terms, and we would be unwise not to utilize it. Killing jobs and economy for the U.S. and Canada only helps Russian totalitarianism.

text:
Nobody likes paying more for things,
But keep in mind what we are getting in return: Cleaner air (and fewer pollution-related problems like asthma and polluted waters), less reliance on foreign powers, more jobs, higher-paying jobs, making America competitive in the industry of renewable energy, less centralization of the power grid, less CO2 in the atmosphere that is driving climate change, and CHEAPER ELECTRICITY! Plus all the as yet undiscovered innovations that will be created as a byproduct of researching and developing new and existing renewable energy sources and related technology!

The future is truly bright. So let's not lose sight of what's at stake over 70 cents

text:
¬†@Logan¬† Well higher gas prices meaning cleaner air could actually be a thing. Higher prices might make people drive less. But that's beside the point because that's not what I meant. I was listing the benefits of focusing effort and investment into renewables. Stopping subsidies helping prop up the economics of fossil fuels would hasten the transition away from such energy sources through normal market forces.

And I would need to see hard numbers of carbon emissions of a 20-year pipeline constructions project (that's a lot of trucks delivering materials to remote areas and entire supply chains behind that contributing to the problem), versus tankers delivering a commodity that will continue to lose demand over the coming years. Investing in a long-term pipeline project would only serve the keep us hooked on oil for years to come.

Quick note about coal jobs. They aren't under threat by alternative energy jobs. Alternative energy only really helps with additional growth, not current usage. Current plants are still needed.

text:
I don't want to hear another goddamned word from him about clean energy until he supports nuclear energy.  The only "clean" energy source that would allow us to have energy independence.  "But it has the word nuclear, and that scares me dur dur dur."    Talk all that good shit about how bad fossil fuels are, but ignore the ONLY way we have, right now, to reach net zero greenhouse emissions with a safety record par excellence and obtain energy independence.  Over 99% fewer deaths in the HISTORY of nuclear power compared to gas, coal, oil, and biomass.  

"But, nuclear waste is scary, I've watched the Simpsons!"  Actually nuclear waste isn't even a big deal.  If you put ALL the nuclear waste that has come from the U.S. from the entire history of nuclear power, it would only fill a football field and stack about 50 feet high.  That's the ENTIRE history of our nuclear power.  Also, there is SO MUCH potential to recycle the waste for further operations that we could, with our technology and science, achieve about a 97% recyclability on all nuclear waste.  Besides that?  Just keep it in dry storage.  As said before, there is so little physical waste that we wouldn't have a problem keeping it.  Each dry storage "barrel" weighs about 100 tons, can't really be moved, and have a tract record of being completely safe.  It's only not safe when we've attempted to take it OUT of dry storage and move it, like idiots.  

Fucking idiots, all.  Don't use the absolute best option we have to combat climate change, because the word "nuclear" sounds scary to the common person.  Don't try to educate them.  I was hoping better of you, Biden.

text:
¬†@Our Middle Age Adventures¬† Well, since you aren't clear about what you want me to look up, I'll assume this is about the fearful "we'll lose our jobs!" thing.  Certain jobs will be lost, yes.  This is what happens when you move into the future with technology as your guide.  Jobs like type setter, blacksmith, file clerk, wheelwrite, Armourer, pumper, floorhand, etc., are going to be lost.  Yes.  Line workers and a lot of factory jobs are going away.  Yes.  Coal miner jobs along with the car painters will be lost.  Yes.  These jobs are ending any way.  You can either replace them or you can cry foul and demand that we continue in the dark ages while other countries move into the 21st century.

This will require retraining.  Yes.  Take someone who worked as a maintenance worker on an oil rig.  This person can be trained to use his/her skill on maintaining various type of clean energy jobs.  

Look this up and get back to me.
author: lifecloud2

text:
¬†@Our Middle Age Adventures¬† One of my favorite quotes is:  "All change feels like loss."  (anonymous)   or how 'bout this:  "Something's lost but something's gained in living every day."  (Joni Mitchell)

In order to move forward, we have to put the past into the history books, close those books, and beginning writing the future.  "Middle age" is a great time to focus on keeping up.  If you continue to hold onto the past, you'll just get old a lot faster.
author: lifecloud2

text: ¬†@Our Middle Age Adventures¬† Biden's moratorium on federal land leasing halts only new leases from being issued. This is about change ... and change takes time.  The idea is not to equate the idea of jobs to just one type of job.

¬†@Mine Finder¬† I'm still laughing because you literally said Biden's plan placed "America first" so I still know that deeply inside your whole Trump support thing, you are a really smart person who unintentionally knew who was the right leader and that is Joe 

want more proof Biden is the right leader, read this letter: 

White House, January 20th, 2021 

My fellow Americans,


As I swore an oath to God and country to serve as your president, I offered a prayer for the 400,000 Americans and counting who have lost their lives this past year from the once-in-a-century pandemic in our midst. They were mothers and fathers, husbands and wives, sons and daughters, friends, neighbors, and colleagues who leave behind grieving loved ones and a nation on edge. 

For the past year, we could not turn to the federal government for a national plan to answer prayers with action ‚Äî until today. In the following pages, you will find my Administration‚Äôs national strategy to beat the COVID-19 pandemic. It is a comprehensive plan that starts with restoring public trust and mounting an aggressive, safe, and effective vaccination campaign. It continues with the steps we know that stop the spread liked expanded masking, testing, and social distancing. It‚Äôs a plan where the federal government works with states, cities, Tribal communities, and private industry to increase supply and administer testing and the vaccines that will help reopen schools and businesses safely. Equity will also be central to our strategy so that the communities and people being disproportionately infected and killed by

the pandemic receive the care they need and deserve.


Our national strategy will be driven by scientists and public health experts who will regularly speak directly to you, free from political interference as they make decisions strictly on science and public health alone. 

Above all, Vice President Harris and I, and our entire Administration, will always be honest and transparent with you about both the good news and the bad. The honest truth is we are still in a dark winter of this pandemic. It will get worse before it gets better. Progress will take time to measure as people getting infected today don‚Äôt show up in case counts for weeks, and those who perish from the disease die weeks after exposure. Even as we make progress, we will face setbacks. But I know we can do it, and that a true national strategy will take all of us working together. It will take Congress providing the necessary funding. Families and neighbors will need to continue looking out for one another. We will need health care providers, businesses, civic, religious and civil rights organizations, and unions all rallying together in common purpose and with urgency, purpose, and resolve. We will need to reassert America‚Äôs leadership in the world in the fight against this and future public health threats.

There are moments in history when more is asked of us as Americans. We are in that moment now and history will measure whether we were up to a task. Beating this pandemic will be one of the most difficult operational challenges we have ever faced as a nation. I believe we are ready, as fellow Americans and as the United States of America.

May God bless the lost souls of this pandemic, and all of you on the frontlines who define the best of who we are as
Americans.


Sincerely, President Joe Biden"

text:
¬†@AdamKey¬†  
After reading all this back and forth about who‚Äôs the biggest polluter, I‚Äôd like to help.  When I hear people proclaiming the ‚Äúuse of science‚Äù, I think it would be fair to ask them to use facts or at least ‚Äútheir facts along with the source of such ‚Äúfacts‚Äù.  
Everybody must have heard that ‚Äúfigures cannot lie, but liars can figure‚Äù. Let‚Äôs see.
With reference to the link below (whose truthfulness I cannot verify, but let‚Äôs say it is making an effort not to skew the data),
https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.usatoday.com/amp/39548763
 
It says the following:
1. China
‚Ä¢ CO2 emissions from fossil fuel (2017): 9,838.8 million metric tons
‚Ä¢ CO2 emissions from fossil fuel per person (2017): 7.1 metric tons
‚Ä¢ Change from CO2 emissions in 1992: 270.3%

2. USA
‚Ä¢ CO2 emissions from fossil fuel (2017): 5,269.5 million metric tons
‚Ä¢ CO2 emissions from fossil fuel per person (2017): 16.2 metric tons
‚Ä¢ Change from CO2 emissions in 1992: 1.8%

From a couple of websites, whose truthfulness I am not questioning, we find:
China‚Äôs pop. 1992: 1,165 billions
China‚Äôs pop. 2017: 1,386 billions
China % pop. incr. since 1992= 19%

USA pop. 1992: 256.51 millions
USA Pop. 2017: 324.99 millions
USA % pop. incr. since 1992= 27%

So China is the largest pollution producer (9,838.8 million metric tons) vs. USA (5,269.5 million metric tons), ALMOST 2X.
However when you divide the total pollution produced, by the respective populations, then The US produces 16.2 metric tons per person, vs.  China at 7.1 metric tons per person. 
Looking at the Pollution Production increase for each country, it is 270.3% China to 1.8% USA. A huge difference. 
Comparing the respective population changes during the same time period, it‚Äôs 27% USA vs. 19% China. 
So for that given time frame even though the USA Population vs. China‚Äôs grew by a higher percentage (27% to 19%) the pollution production per capita, by China grew by a 150X factor vs. that of the USA. Amazing! Is it not?
Another thing the pollution production increase numbers tell me is that using the per capita calculation is not indicative of shit. The total pollution must be broken down into its largest producers. Blaming the average Joe and saddling him/her with causing all this ‚Äúaverage‚Äù pollution, is totally  bullshit and unfair to Joe. I would be comfortable saying  that most pollution is probably generated by the manufacturing sector. 
So from the above analysis (mine), I think it would be fair to say that China ABSOLUTELY generates around TWICE the pollution the US generates.
That is science (maybe?)üòÄ

¬†@Ryan Takahashi¬† Fracking was supposed to be the alternative, to conventional oil supplies, wasn't it ?

author: John Somebody

text: ¬†@John Somebody¬† ? Pretty much everything to do with fracking and oil is bad for the environment and isn‚Äôt sustainable so we have to make the switch eventually, why not now before it gets harder
author: Ryan Shull

text:
¬†@John Somebody¬† No, fracking was the alternative to make the US become energy independent. Rather than relying heavily on foreign oil. Fracking was already a thing before the push towards renewable energy. Natural gas has also heavily reduced our dependency on coal. Which isn't clean, but it's definitely cleaner than coal. You can't just replace an entire industry without having it's replacement in place, otherwise their will be devastating consequences. That's why Biden is trying to push heavily into renewables so that fracking can be reduced over time and eventually phased out completely. Just as we have done with coal over the last 50 years.

It's not a detour because we are already doing it. It's a means to the end. Coal usage has already dropped, but renewable only makes up like 20% of our energy right now. The majority of it comes from oil, gas, and coal. 80 years ago, coal was the largest producer of energy. Today it makes up less than 15%. 20 years ago, it made up almost 25%. The transition period always takes a long time.

Had the US started heavily investing in renewables, especially solar and wind, 20 years ago, instead of constantly propping up the fossil fuel energy sector, we would have been a lot further along. And China wouldn't be the leader in that regard.

So it what world do you suddenly expect fracking to suddenly end? What will replace our energy needs? Common sense dictates that we need to have a replacement in order to shut down fracking. As more renewables come on line, as more appliances convert to electric instead of gas, as more cars become more efficient and transition into fully electric, etc. the need for oil and fracking will go down. If it were feasible to shut it down right now, Biden probably would try. But again, common sense dictates that would literally cripple us. What do you expect to fill the 30-40% gap in energy that would come from cutting off fracking right now?

Every one that believe that climate change is real, and takes it seriously knows that we need to start doing something and get the ball rolling, and that we should have started a long time ago.
author: Ryan Takahashi

text:
¬†@Ryan Shull¬† Absolutely right on !

text:
¬†@LETS GET TURNT¬† I have no idea why there are still people with such limited thinking.   Evidently when someone says "jobs" to you you automatically think there's only one sort of job.  Hmm, I wonder if this is what all those who were shocked when we no longer needed blacksmiths were thinking when their world changed.  "OH!  How will I ever get my horse shod!?"  "What about all those good blacksmith jobs!"  In order for us to create a better future, we have to let go of the past.  

I'm all for ending fracking, but I understand that this is a process and not something that happens over night.  You evidently envision some job boss calling his employees together and saying, "Sorry guys ... yer all fired!"  

When those who worked in the Ford plant were painting new cars, what OH what did they do when this task became mechanized?  And what about those milkmen who showed up with milk delivery every morning?  What about the men who put down tracks for the railroad?  Etc., etc.  Time to think about the future and stop living in the 1950s.  If we're going to compete with other countries who are currently embracing a new way of working in the world, we've got to keep current with a changing world.  And the world is indeed changing.  It can be a positive change or a deadly one, this is up to people like you.

text:
¬†@LETS GET TURNT¬† HA!  I've heard this excuse before:  "Why should I question what I'm told when it takes SO much trouble to do so?"  Fine, don't question.  Don't listen to CNN.  Doesn't matter to me what you believe.  But when you start preaching this opinion based hogwash as truth, that's when it gets to be a problem.  

Let me say this once again:  Over the past four plus years I've watched EVERY single irritating, obnoxious, rambling, incoherent speech trump has ever made.  I've sat through his rantings and name calling and cutesy bullying.  I've also watched Fox and Oann and Newsmax (granted, I couldn't take much of this, especially Hannity and Jeanine Shapiro and Greg Gutfed, but I did try).  I do like Chris Wallace, the last man with integrity at Fox).  

I've been able to see through them right away ... and not because I'm special but because they're obvious.  Newsmax and Oann are just poor journalists, often making grammar errors and mispronouncing names.  I've watched their "reporters" ask trump questions while he was still doing press briefings (which was laughable).  These "questions" were veiled praise that a three year old could see through, but trump lapped it up.  

I watched Stephanie Myers of Oann, dressed to the nines, ask trump something that sounded like, "Why is it that everyone is so jealous of how amazing you are?"  Gag!  And these are the people you believe know what they're talking about.  

I would wager that you had very little interest in politics prior to Obama and that you became really engaged when your boy trump took office.  Then, I would also wager, that it wasn't a matter of politics, but a matter of "team spirit" ... a personality contest.  This is how cults form.  Mostly when you aren't paying attention but digging in because of your team.  And as you're not noticing what you're actually doing, you're taking the entire Republican party (that used to be respected and honorable) and turning it into some sort of mud wrestling team that you're cheering on regardless of what they're doing.

And in the meantime, almost 550,000 people have died, we've become the laughing stock of the world, our foreign relations is in shambles, and the worst aspects of who we are as Americans are held up as some sort of badge of honor.  

You have no idea what's going on in the country or where we'd be now if trump did win another term.  Take a look around you and try to see past the smoke and mirrors!

Early 2014 Hunter Biden associate Devon Archer joins Burisma board. Archer was the top fundraiser for secretary of state John Kerry
16 April 2014 Devon Archer visits VP Joe Biden in the white house
18 April Hunter Biden with no experience in the oil industry whatsoever joins the board of Burisma. Burisma then paid $90 000 to ML strategies lobbying firm headed by David Leiter (john Kerry's former chief of staff) then Kerry visited Ukraine with promises of aid for the oil industry.
21 April VP Joe Biden promises billions US tax dollar aid to Ukraine oil industry to help ramp up production. ML strategies paid $60 000 to dem senators Gene Shaheen and Ed Markey.
These two senators in June 2014 wrote to Obama requesting that more aid be given to Ukraine's energy industry to increase their oil and gas production. Ed Markey was the senate sponsor of the Green New Deal as championed by Biden to shut down US gas production but increase Ukraine production.
By the end of Obama's term in 2018 the USA had given $3billion of aid and loan guarantees to Ukraine to ramp up production. Do you really believe that the dems are worried about carbon emissionsJoe Biden bragged about how he got the prosecutor in Ukraine firedby blackmailing the Ukrainians by threatening to withhold $1 000 000 000 in aid unless the president of Ukraine fires the prosecutor. text: ¬†@MAC LESTER¬† No one is denying that mineral extraction for clean energy sources is a problem that needs to be addressed. Yes, CO2 is not a dominant gas in the atmosphere, but even slight increases have a detrimental impact on Earth's ecology. Climate changes over hundreds of thousands of years, even millions of years, but the issue today is that climate is changing at a rapid speed because of human activities. We see the consequences every year, record heat waves, record storms, record sea-level rise, record fires, record ocean acidification, record extinction, record drought, etc. The change is so rapid that nature and humans are unable to adapt. Imagine the refugee and water crisis of the future. We could barely handle 100 thousand Syrian refugees imagine hundreds of millions as a result of climate degradation. Transitioning our energy sector requires thinking locally, using renewable technology on a small scale, microgrids, installing solar panels on every house so they become self-sufficient. No one is saying eliminate oil, we understand that oil is essential for petroleum products like plastic. What we are saying is to change the way we power our cities, and change the way we transport our goods and people. Transforming our sources of electricity, and eliminating the combustion engine is how we will solve this crisis. And no, renewable sources are actually incredibly powerful and very effective, especially when done on a smaller, more manageable scale. Again, you're also missing the point that this is an opportunity to create millions of jobs. Nuclear? No thanks. I don't care how powerful and carbon-neutral nuclear power is, you can never convince me that radioactive waste is a good idea.
author: Anobel Khoushabeh

Green energy means transforming everything from the way we power our house, to the way we light up our roads. Clean energy doesn't require massive infrastructures like oil and gas, that's the beauty of it.

text:
@MAC LESTER  Do you really believe the lies that you're spewing? Cause if you do there's no point in people wasting time with you.

BOTH water vapour and CO2 absorb infrared radiation. But there are two key differences. One, water vapour sits low in the atmosphere, whereas CO2 goes up as high as 50km. This higher altitude makes CO2 much more prominent in absorbing infrared radiation. Secondly, and much more importantly, water vapor does not control the Earth‚Äôs temperature, but is instead controlled by the temperature.  The amount of water molecules on the planet don't change. Water is either a vapour in the atmosphere or a liquid on the ground, this state changes based on the temperature. Whereas CO2 in the atmosphere keeps on increasing as humans take carbon out of the ground and by burning it, dump it into the atmosphere where it just keeps collecting and absorbing infrared radiation.

text:
¬†@Laura Venter¬† Watch this speech, it's beautyful, highly Presidential and intelectual and it will leave you in tears, a materpice of public speaking www://.youtube.com/watchv=rmN90VuLH6Y 

And second, read this awesome letter from our President:
"White House, January 20, 2021
 
My fellow Americans,

As I swore an oath to God and country to serve as your president, I offered a prayer for the 400,000 Americans and counting who have lost their lives this past year from the once-in-a-century pandemic in our midst. They were mothers and fathers, husbands and wives, sons and daughters, friends, neighbors, and colleagues who leave behind grieving loved ones and a nation on edge.

For the past year, we could not turn to the federal government for a national plan to answer prayers with action ‚Äî until today. In the following pages, you will find my Administration‚Äôs national strategy to beat the COVID-19 pandemic. It is a comprehensive plan that starts with restoring public trust and mounting an aggressive, safe, and effective vaccination campaign. It continues with the steps we know that stop the spread liked expanded masking, testing, and social distancing. It‚Äôs a plan where the federal government works with states, cities, Tribal communities, and private industry to increase supply and administer testing and the vaccines that will help reopen schools and businesses safely. Equity will also be central to our strategy so that the communities and people being disproportionately infected and killed by the pandemic receive the care they need and deserve.

Our national strategy will be driven by scientists and public health experts who will regularly speak directly to you, free from political interference as they make decisions strictly on science and public health alone. 

Above all, Vice President Harris and I, and our entire Administration, will always be honest and transparent with you about both the good news and the bad. The honest truth is we are still in a dark winter of this pandemic. It will get worse before it gets better. Progress will take time to measure as people getting infected today don‚Äôt show up in case counts for weeks, and those who perish from the disease die weeks after exposure. Even as we make progress, we will face setbacks. But I know we can do it, and that a true national strategy will take all of us working together. It will take Congress providing the necessary funding. Families and neighbors will need to continue looking out for one another. We will need health care providers, businesses, civic, religious and civil rights organizations, and unions all rallying together in common purpose and with urgency, purpose, and resolve. We will need to reassert America‚Äôs leadership in the world in the fight against this and future public health threats. 

There are moments in history when more is asked of us as Americans. We are in that moment now and history will measure whether we were up to a task. Beating this pandemic will be one of the most difficult operational challenges we have ever faced as a nation. I believe we are ready, as fellow Americans and as the United States of America.

May God bless the lost souls of this pandemic, and all of you on the frontlines who define the best of who we are as Americans.

Sincerely and respectfully, President Joseph R. Biden"

This screams leadership, kindness, strength, good policy and good leadership, this is a trustworthy man, this man is a leader, a man born to be a servant of the his people, and that is what he is, God Bless our President Joe Biden, join me in my best wishes for this great President because I know you are a smart woman, and you know how to pick the right leader, well this is it, have a good night.

text: No disrespect to your President Biden, but I think we are doing a pretty good job about making our air cleaner.  I remember the days driving through Toronto Canada, and one almost had to cover the face with a cloth because of the horrible smell of sulphur and other chemicals as one passed through the city on the 401 express highway and sighing relief after you got out of the city into the country side.  Today you could almost bottle the beautiful air and sell it .  Politicians seem to use climate change to make it look like they are doing something special.  As a teenager living in the northern part of Canada, my summer job was fighting forest fires for a little extra money.  It was great money I think about fifty five cents an hour.  Northern Ontario has thousands of miles of nothing but lakes and bush as far as the eye can see, but you know what?  Those hundreds of fires a summer were mostly caused by lightning.  Yes a few by American tourists, (tongue in cheek, but hey we loved the money that came into the area, just a little joke).  Nature is the main cause of our forest fires.  Forest fires have been happening since the beginning of time. It is natures way of actually cleansing the earth. The ash etc. as fertilizer and the new growth etc.  To see the results after a few years is amazing.  Politics today in the USA seems to be like a raging forest fire.  People trying to destroy each other verbally.  Looking south, from up here, I think the USA needs a third party.  With only two parties and the news media on one side or the other, using you past president Trump as an example, the media can hound a person half to death as we have witnessed.  This is not good for your country.  More parties to vote for can eliminate most of this as now the news wants to promote which party is the best for the people, and mostly show the good points of each party.  They say there may have been cheating going on but if it doesn't get to court who really knows for sure, but from up here watching the hate for each other and the badmouthing is starting to hurt our feelings because this is exactly what Communist China wants to happen.  They want the USA destroyed from the inside out and it seems to be working right now.  Canadians have always had your back and you ours.  I am sorry to rant like this, but if in some little way, it can change thinking then good for us both.  God bless our good old friends to the south.  God bless the USA.

text:
¬†@Miguel Batista¬† Obviously adding heat and/or chemicals into an environmental system changes that system, I never said it didn't. I'm just saying we should look at the big long term picture and act accordingly. Unfortunately people want to look at one small aspect of the subject and jump on the "that's BAD" bandwagon without really understanding much of anything. Limiting population growth and preferably having negative population growth for a while until we get down to realistically manageable number of humans would be the most practical and sensible solution but I can already hear the gasps of horror at that suggestion! ;-) people want to live where they want and have what ever they want but they don't want to give up anything and want more. 

How do we reduce pollution? People need to live in walking distance or bike riding distance from where they work and shop. People need to only eat foods that are grown locally. People need to only buy products that are manufactured locally. That would be a good start.

Forgive my ignorance, but if the earth is billions of years old, according to science and during these billions of years, the earth has gone through climate change as long as it has been in existence. According to science we‚Äôve had several ice ages and according to science the earth‚Äôs climate transitions between cold and warm periods.

I think they‚Äôre called called Milankovitch (sp?) cycles. There‚Äôs an interchange, periodically, of ice ages. When it‚Äôs cold it called a glacial period and when it‚Äôs warm it‚Äôs called interglacial.

Add in the fact that according to science we‚Äôve not discovered every spot of land on earth and we‚Äôve only tackled 5% of the ocean, so how do we know exactly the toll our actions as humans have on the climate? According to science, the climate was and is and always will be destined to change.

I do believe we should do better and use common sense and be considerate of our planet. However at this point, it seems like putting lipstick on a pig. That bell was rung a long time ago.

Anyhoo, I‚Äôd appreciate your thoughts. Thanks üòä

text:
¬†@Steve Marquez¬† 
Well ... funny you should say that.

You already get a decent subsidy for buying electric, as do we here. It may well increase. That coupled with the falling price of EV ownership over the next couple of years will go a long way to accelerating change.
Believe it or not ... our government is now supplying EV's to local government and civil service, councils and the like.
By 2030 you won't be able to buy an ICE vehicle here. It won't be allowed.

Tesla are not only releasing the semi  this year but are designing an entry level vehicle for around $19,000. It may be in production this year. With government subsidies and attractive ownership incentives that could come down a lot further.
Let's not forget it will also be the first model to make up a fully autonomous robo taxi fleet which again ... will change the whole concept of car ownership entirely. An owner will make money from their EV ... driving down costs further.

The energy density in modern batteries is already sufficient to begin looking at electric boats as a realistic option over the next few years. There are already million mile batteries with 6 - 700 miles range and that's increasing all the time.

Helicopters ... then maybe one day planes. Though air travel in itself could be tolerable for now if all other criteria are met.

Oil as a fuel not only is dead but necessarily has to be made dead and buried.
I think you'll be surprised at how quickly things will change over this decade. The likes of B.P have already announced their reduced production timeline up to 2035 and the immediate start of their own transition to a net zero, green energy company by 2050.

2050.
That's what Biden said.
Net zero emissions by 2050.
2035 is the date set out in the Paris accord.
You aren't doing enough.
You are still not honouring your global obligations.
You still don't seem to grasp the severity of our current existential human predicament.
This is a climate 'crisis'.
We should be acting like it.
You seem to think we have a choice in any of this?
We do not.
We are screwed.
It is now about survival, and trust me ... in the coming years that won't be granted to all no matter what we do now.
The earth is changing.
We are on it.
It's time to stop sticking our heads in the sand and deal with it as best as we can.

Wake up friend.
We can't stop it now.
It's too late.
This is about mitigation.

You guys need to make this your next Apollo program ... but on a much grander scale.
When you're starting from so far behind all the others you need to do more in the beginning to catch up in the end.

To paraphrase.
You are not a commodity. You are not traded as such on the markets and we do not use 'Steve's' as a metric of global currency stability.
I'm afraid to say that your countries economic system will not die if you die.
You are a physical agent ... not a barrel of oil. You are not a market and do not possess the means to supply the nation with the necessary energy and resources to sustain a population.

We know when the countries of the world are going to abandon it.
It will never peak again, never boom or grow, and all investment and global demand disappear.
Everyone else advances ... you stay still as the clock counts down to inevitability.

There's an urgency now required in transitioning our countries out of their dependence upon a dying market. Nature rang the bell on it and now it's going to start having serious financial implications as demand plummets and it becomes harder to sustain.

It's dead.

text:
¬†@Steve Marquez¬† xl pipeline is 1500 
Miles from the ocean. Stfu. 

From Newsweek:

When the State Department released their report on the Keystone XL pipeline last month, news media focused on the report's conclusion that the pipeline would not significantly worsen carbon pollution. The finding was broadly declared a win for advocates of the project, who are now imploring the White House to approve it.

But buried in the 11-chapter report was a less sunny detail: the Keystone XL would create only 35 permanent jobs after the one or two years of construction jobs dry up.

"Once the proposed Project enters service, operations would require an estimated 50 total employees: 35 permanent employees and 15 temporary contractors," the State Department wrote.

Republican supporters of the pipeline have long said the project would be a major job creator. In 2012, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce took out a full page ad in the New York Times warning President Obama not to say "no" to "20,000 jobs," a number taken from the pipeline company's estimates.

NEWSWEEK SUBSCRIPTION OFFERS >
When Sen. Johnny Isakson (Ga.-R) said in a speech in 2012 that the pipeline would "employ 20,000 people," the fact-checking site PolitiFact rated his statement as "false." PolitiFact noted that even if one were to accept the pipeline company's job number, each "job" is counted as one "job year." That means that if the construction project lasted two years, one employee working for two years would be counted as having two "jobs," leaving the number of employees at somewhere closer to 10,000.

The latest State Department report, which also defines a "job" as a position filled for one year, estimates that the project would create 16,100 jobs directly related to Keystone XL. Another approximately 26,000 year-long jobs would created indirectly (restaurant and store workers, for example, needed to accommodate the temporarily increased population along the pipeline). That brings the State Department's total to 42,100 year-long jobs.

RELATED STORIES
Keystone Pipeline Would Save 6 Lives a Year, Report Says
Keystone Pipeline Will Not Affect Canada Oil Sands Growth: U.S. Report
Included in that number, the report estimates that about 10,400 seasonal workers would be recruited for construction of the pipeline for jobs lasting four to eight months. If those short stints are calculated into an average annual jobs, that works out to 3,900 jobs over one year of construction, or 1,950 jobs each year for two years, the State Department wrote. After one to two years, the vast majority would leave, and 35 people would be permanently employed, according to the report.

Last year, Obama dismissed the claim that the pipeline could reduce unemployment in the U.S., calling the potential impact of Keystone XL a "blip" in terms of job creation.

NEWSWEEK SUBSCRIPTION OFFERS >
"Republicans have said that this would be a big jobs generator," Mr. Obama said in an interview with the New York Times. "There is no evidence that that's true. The most realistic estimates are this might create maybe 2,000 jobs during the construction of the pipeline, which might take a year or two, and then after that we're talking about somewhere between 50 and 100 jobs in an economy of 150 million working people."

A 2011 study conducted by Cornell University's ILR Global Labor Institute, which works with trade unions on environmental and other challenges, concluded that the Keystone XL pipeline could actually destroy more jobs than it created. The study takes into account job loss that would be caused if Midwesterners end up paying 10 to 20 cents more per gallon of gas due to the pipeline diverting oil from Midwest refineries to the Gulf region.

"Furthermore, pipeline spills, pollution and increased greenhouse gas emissions incur significant human health and economic costs, thus eliminating jobs," Sean Sweeney, director of the Cornell ILR Global Labor Institute, said in a statement.

For now, the White House says Obama will wait at least 90 days from the release of the State Department report before deciding whether to approve the pipeline.

text:
¬†@Steve Marquez¬† 
We're doing brilliant thanks. The vast majority of Scotland's energy supply comes from wind so high winds provide an overabundance of offshore energy supply generated amply by the turbines. We do also have other options like nuclear power and hydroelectric energy production to draw from. 
As you know ... Scotland isn't the sunniest of places at the best of times and so we've maximised other sources to suit in our energy mix.

There have been some localised power outages due to faults in the transmission networks, but that's hardly anything to do with green energy. If anything it's just another reason to accelerate the transition to renewables by investing in battery storage and the localising of power distribution grids.
Ironically ... in the greener world of tomorrow no household would lose electric supply in a storm. Each home would be autonomous and separate from the grid. Self sufficient with a full battery of storage in the house.
Local sub stations would hold redundancy in larger power bank battery storage units that could continue to supply energy during almost any 'epic disaster'.

There is an epic disaster happening.
The climate crisis.
It's happening right in front of your face. A short mini ice age is but a precursor to the true glacial freeze of a more permanent ice age vacation. 
We've been here before.
It's just not something you'd expect to see so dramatically in an inter glacial period. As the gulf stream moved south before the last ice age, Canada, North America, Europe, Russia and Siberia ... were engulfed by an advancing glacial ice sheet.

I like a bit of snow for a few days or weeks at a time ... but not for millennia.
One day the gulf stream might not snap back.

text: People don't like fusion because they are dangerous, and they also do have waste
author: Cucumamacacapipi

text:
¬†@Cucumamacacapipi¬† Please do not confuse Fusion with FISSION. Fusion is not dangerous. The reaction can be stopped as easily as turning off the hydrogen feed valves and bringing the plasma temperature down. The latter is done by turning off the fuel hydrogen. If the plasma cools, it does not collide, it does not fuse.

The free Neutrons can be captured more readily than stopping the basic nuclear decay of fissile materials. And not every fusion reaction even produces neutrons. The holy grail is Helium-3 fusion, which will produce none. Though the fuel material is a little more complex to produce than splitting sea water.
author: CharlyDeamen

text:
¬†@Cucumamacacapipi¬† You may be right in what people think, so there needs to be more public education on the topic. Though fusion reactors also will not be completely risk-free (as is basically no sort of energy-production - even photovoltaic fires are really dangerous and hard to put out), they are way less dangerous than fission reactors, which they are going to replace and produce only a small fraction of the amount of waste, that even has a much, much shorter radioactive half-life.

Fusion is the most promising basline-power technology that can add to renewables when wind doesn't blow and sun doesn't shine and there are not enough rivers for water-power (which has it's own considerable problems on marine life) and can in the long term replace fission and fossil energy.
author: Bitfire31337

text:
¬†@Bitfire31337¬† Also, and while I am not a LICENCED nuclear physicist (I have read some books) I am wondering... and this is blue sky thinking... if one day those free neutrons can become the basis of a secondary energy-generating system. By what I understand, free Neutrons decay (in under 15 mins) into a proton, electron, and an antineutrino (antimatter). Charged particles can be confined with magnetic fields. If, theoretically if... that antimatter is made to annihilate with that same proton... wouldn't that be more energy released? The free electron (if captured) could be channeled into electricity directly. There might be some gamma ray bursts out of that, but... again, blue sky thinking.... we can confine that.

Would love to sit down with an actual nuclear physicist and gab for hours. Can you tell?
author: CharlyDeamen

text:
¬†@Ethan S¬† Please don't talk about the hydrogen fuel cell. It's a dodo tech. It's basically big oil, except you swap the chemical compound they sell you. Instead of a hydrocarbon, they just give you the hydrogen. It will still have to be extracted (energy required for that), stored (energy required for that), shipped to hydrogen pumping stations (energy required for that), and then recombined to extract energy (inefficient process). The whole thing violates the principles of simple is best, and will lose to ANY tech that obeys "simple is best" better. IE the EV.

And then you have the fundamental fact that hydrogen is FAR more combustible. One errant static spark and kaboom. Hydrocabons require a very specific mix of fume-form and oxygen and then a spark. Yea... not. the HFC is NOT happening. It's bad energy economy and dangerous in the hands of careless consumers. The more people handle it, the more likely that stuff WILL go wrong due to that glorious "human error" variable. Now if they want to make Hydrogen cell fueled BUSES, ships, etc... it MIGHT be possible. But the energy density of hydrogen is quite... mediocre for that.

text:
¬†@Ravenclaw¬† Again. ITER. Heating costs? 50 megawatt. Will produce 500 megawatt for it. The previous generation fusion reactors were small scale material science testbeds. The ITER is a dress rehearsal.

ITER uses ALL hydrogen. Deuterium and Tritum. Helium 3 is a holy grail, and it's actually quite abundant in the lunar regolith (and the atmospheres of gas giants... but we're aiming for the Moon first, it's a LOT closer than Jupiter). Space X is making space exploration quite economic. Putting a solar-powered dozer on the moon, and then launching reusable ore hoppers for it to fill. Which are then sent back and retrieved. Not blue sky thinking. Lunar escape velocity is about 2km/s. Getting something heavy off the moon, much easier than off the Earth (our escape velocity is 11.2 km/s)
