author: CharlyDeamen

text:
¬†@CharlyDeamen¬† I'm only a long-term layman physicist myself. But I found your idea interesting and did some research:
First off, we're talking about deuterium + tritium fusion here, which is the current state of technology and what ITER will be doing. Deuterium / Deuterium and Deuterium / Helium-3 work differently and produce less or no neutrons.

1. The neutrons carry most of the fusion's energy (14,1 MeV) as kinetic energy and (as far as we know) can't be confined, so they collide with the walls of the reactor, which heats it up (which is then used to heat water and run a turbine). As far as I understand, free neutrons are usually caught by some atom quickly, so neutrons are rarely free long enough to go through their beta-decay or it will be quite tricky to do that.

2. If we found some way to prevent the above and harness free neutrons until they decay, there are two parts that could in theory give more energy:
a) The electron, as you said, should be rather simple to catch - free electricity (I guess?!).
b) The anti-(electron)-neutrino would probably be more difficult to get to annihilate as neutrinos don't interact much with anything, as you know. But what you describe is something like the Cowan‚ÄìReines neutrino experiment (see Wikipedia): So if it annihilates, this happens: Antineutrino + proton --> neutron (again) + positron ("anti-electron"). The latter annihilates with an electron and produces two gamma rays (= photons) with an energy sum of about 1 MeV, while the neutron will usually be caught by some core (again, if not somehow contained). So, 1 MeV is rather measly in comparison to the 14 MeV from the neutron's kinetic energy, which we can mostly harvest.
Also note that you would have to put an electron into the annihilation first, so I don't know if the net energy outcome would even in theory be positive.

Hope I got this about right, just learned parts of it myself. Maybe we still get lucky and some real nuclear physisicst chimes in to enlighten us ;-).
author: Bitfire31337

text: ¬†@CharlyDeamen¬† Consistent, reliable fusion reactors aren't going to happen on the timescale we need them to, and they certainly aren't going to be wide spread enough. I'm all for fusion energy since that will be the best clean energy we can achieve with our current physical models (unless we start getting into anti-matter and potential negative energy fields, but that's getting a little too theoretical), but the best we've done thus far is a 20 second reactor. Our best bet will probably be Thorium reactors (I'm a fan of the LFTR design).
author: DELTA BOT

text: ¬†@Bitfire31337¬† I appreciate any input. Not a professional myself. I was kind of tossing a wild and wooly idea. If it does not work, then it does not work. But science plays with the "maybes". Even failures / "not efficient"s can be used to learn ~something~. Or they can be the launch of something else. I'm spit-balling.

author: Ethan S

text:
¬†@DELTA BOT¬† I'm sorry, but I have to disagree. Just because the time frame is "inconvenient", it does not mean that it wont be done, or worse... shouldn't be done. If nothing is done, we're going to have a problem when fossil fuels plainly run out. The resource wars THAT will naturally incur will NOT be pretty.

Basically, the ITER is a one design, it looks like doughnut... It's called a TOKAMAK. They're expecting it to peak at longer-rate 500 megawatt reactions. Reaction duration, confining that much heat/energy... that's part of its development. It's just one more thing to figure out. It will be figured out. And I've ready about alternative geometries, the "Stellarators". Five-fold, four-fold... there's more than there. The designs for the fusion reactors are as myriad as there were tweaks to airframes in the first ten years after the Wright Flier took off (biplanes, triplanes, all manner of crazy experiments), but at the end of that evolutionary chain was something as gargantuan as the AN225, it gets off the ground just fine. Point is, we'll get there. Because we have to.
author: CharlyDeamen

text: ¬†@CharlyDeamen¬† You didn't get what I said: yes, we should be working toward Fusion energy, but we need an interim because it won't be ready on the timeframe we need.
author: DELTA BOT

text:
¬†@DELTA BOT¬† Sorry I realized that. My bad...
Well interim we have the dropping prices on solar. Pushing ever closer toward that $1.00/w "goldilocks" zone (that's installation/panel costs of $1 per watt it can produce). With the technologies that's going to require. Including storage and what goes into that storage medium. At the risk of sounding like a Tesla fan, the whispers I've been hearing about the new "Tabless" batteries Tesla is working on... that's something. There are also solid state battery breakthroughs on the horizon. It's one more way of doing  "interim".

I'm interested in this idea of a "virtual power plant". Suppose every new home had solar panels (or juice-generating shingles) as stock (because they became cheaper) and batteries. Whatever juice that is NOT used, but generated by those panels, gets "sold" on to the grid. So there's your virtual, decentralized power plant possibility. Fill in the gaps with hydro power, wind, tidal, with your idea of a few small, "nuclear kettles". We might just be able to bridge the gaps.
author: CharlyDeamen

text: ¬†@Ethan S¬† Bio hydrogen, as in distilled bio-fuel from organic matter? I really think it falls under the same category as the HFC. Growing all that biomass is storing energy, it will require energy to do, and while rotten corn is fine (no need for pesticides?) processing it for bio-fuel will take energy. Transporting that bio hydrogen is more energy expenditure. And then what is the energy density on that? Again, is it setting up a violation of the "simple is best"?
author: CharlyDeamen

text:
¬†@r e¬† Fusion does not create any materials with very long half-lives. It does not use isotopes of Uranium, Plutonium, or generate Strontium 90, which will linger for decades, or in some cases, even hundreds of years.

Whatever radiation is used, from the tritum, with proper shielding of the facility, simply cannot leave the premises because it is stabilizing in the process of fusion.

Fusion is also not something that can happen in a runaway chain reaction unlike a radioactive material reaching critical mass. The worst one might have is a catastrophic explosion, but again, it does not, and WILL not release fissile materials and isotopes that do not break down slower than continental drift. It does not produce nuclear waste that has to be buried deep underground.

Spin it all you like, but Fusion is about 99% safer.
author: CharlyDeamen

text: ¬†@r e¬† Burning coal and fossil fuels releases more in trace radiation than a nuclear reactor could dream of. There are plenty of reactor designs that contain virtually 100% of their waste radiation; if you're talking about waste fuel, there are plenty of storage/disposal methods for the fuel once it's used (which takes a VERY long time). What do you mean 'abnormalities'? Radiation doesn't cause Fallout style mutations. Either way, if you're going to criticize someone else for lack of education, the least you could do is be versed in the subject yourself.
author: DELTA BOT

text: ¬†@DELTA BOT¬† Yea, I love Fallout (the games) but they really botched that "mutated thing". I mean we have long-term data from Chernobyl and the surrounding red zone around Pripyat. Last I've heard, they have all sorts of critters moving into the area, since humans are still not there, and they're not growing huge, or growing second heads, or added limbs. Deer in the area do breed. Wolves breed (and being carnivores they would accumulate even more of the radiation).
author: CharlyDeamen

text:
And I mentioned Strontium 90 for a reason. That isotope has the lovely propensity of replacing calcium in bones (and teeth). One it gets in, it does not get out. And it's half life is around 30 years.

Tritium can't do something like that. Even when it bonds with oxygen to create toxic water. It would have to be constant, unremitted leakage of that stuff to contaminate water so thoroughly. And even then, Tritium's half life is around 12 years. Then there is a difference is how it decays to begin with. Add to that, its biological decay (if it does enter the body) is measured in days! Out of everything that I know, it doesn't seem to be that big an issue if SAFETY MEASURES are enforced. And when dealing with tritium, that's probably easier.

text:
¬†@Dorian Shades of gray¬† I understand they are genuine concerns, but they can be mitigated against. Also, unemployment did not rise under Obama, the economy grew, unemployment fell from 8% to under 5% and incomes grew faster than inflation nationally.

But yes I understand that rural America fears democratic policy as it doesn‚Äôt adequately address how to mitigate the negative impacts on the small communities and towns that may be left behind.

However other countries have shown it can be done without leaving an economy in tatters with sky high unemployment. It‚Äôs possible to scale back fossil fuel production and replace it with renewable energy which is more cost effective, more sustainable longer term and pays better wages. But it‚Äôs all about what to do with the people currently working in those industries who fear what will happen to their livelihoods.

It‚Äôs a debate that needs to be had, and I hope progress can continue to be made, as it always has been. Just remember that 60 years ago, there were way more jobs in manual work than there are now, but over time the economy shifted to more white collar work than blue collar, as all rich western countries have over the 20th century.
author: Tyler Hopcroft

text:
¬†@Tyler Hopcroft¬† I‚Äôve got no problem with renewables eventually taking over fossil fuels  , however we are not there yet as the reliability and cost of batteries to store renewable energy for when the sun doesn‚Äôt shine and the wind isn‚Äôt blowing  isn‚Äôt cheap enough yet to compete with coal.
This will eventually happen but I believe we should allow the market to determine the timing of when this happens rather than try to force the change. I guarantee when the market decides that renewables are more economical than fossil fuels , then fossil fuels will disappear as fast as 8 track players  and VCRs .
author: Dorian Shades of gray

text:
¬†@Dorian Shades of gray¬† But the market is always short term rather than long term looking, so the market will continue to pollute the environment if that‚Äôs the cheapest option unless there‚Äôs government intervention. Cars have become way less polluting over the years, primarily through the work of government rather than the free market which has little to no incentive to make cars pollute less.

These are called externalities, effects of economic activity which are external to the market which determines their price. One of the primary causes of government intervention into a market is to eliminate these externalities whether it be alcohol licensing, gambling regulations, reducing harmful toxins in cigarettes, protecting national parks from deforestation and mining etc etc. The same applies to slowly and carefully shifting to renewables.

In fact, shifting in a controlled manner will likely be better than if the market does it as it‚Äôs more likely to be done far more quickly and abruptly by the free market, as you said, which would be a much bigger shock to the people and communities who work in fossil fuel industries if they all lose their jobs pretty much overnight if renewables suddenly become cheaper and more efficient.
author: Tyler Hopcroft

text:
¬†@Tyler Hopcroft¬† those are fair points  and I do agree with them when applied to local markets within a country , however when it comes the energy market, I think it‚Äôs a different story. It‚Äôs a very competitive world out there and companies have to minimise costs to compete against a global market . So if governments increase  the cost of energy  by installing costly renewable power plants and storage batteries and impose costly environment regulations  for these companies to manufacture their goods, then these companies will simply offshore their business to other countries that have lower energy costs , lower labour cost and less regulations.
Now if the whole world reduced their emission together then  everyone would be on an equal footing and we might be able to force the change over to renewables . However,  China and india are the biggest carbon emitters in the world and they don‚Äôt have to start reducing  their emissions until 2030. So that‚Äôs  why governments have such resistance to investing in 100% renewables , because it could destroy their economy and give significant competitive advantage to countries like China and India .
author: Dorian Shades of gray

text:
¬†@Dorian Shades of gray¬† Oh yes you‚Äôre absolutely right and that is one of the arguments green activists never seem to successfully argue against.

It‚Äôs a difficult balance to strike, so hopefully with new innovation and gov subsidies the cost can be reduced to compete effectively with fossil fuels. With the rate I‚Äôd technological advancement in this field, I think that‚Äôs not too far away.
